</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">These fragments give an idea of the range of patterns employed by glassmakers in this most popular vessel form. The variations seem almost endless, and the patterns range from strikingly bold (as in cat. 85 and cat. 86) to a more overall pattern (as in cat. 84). The shape was fabricated in many sizes that must have served as smaller sauce containers to drinking vessels and smaller serving bowls, all with some variation on the characteristic outsplayed rim and double carinated profile.

Compare these fragments with the complete mosaic bowl (cat. 83), and the monochrome examples (cat. 81 and cat. 82). The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has a fragment (fig. 1) with ground and cane configuration similar to cat. 85. Another example in the Met (fig. 2) has a pattern similar to cat. 86.  
Sidney Goldstein
